newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.AFRICAN HOTELS' PROFITABILITY DIPS SHARPLY IN Q2.
newsitem.headline: S.AFRICAN HOTELS' PROFITABILITY DIPS SHARPLY IN Q2.

text.p: The profitability of South African hotels dipped sharply in the second quarter of this year compared to the first quarter, the Central Statistical Service (CSS) said on Monday.
The profitability ratio (net profit over turnover) fell to 10.4 percent from 18.6 percent in the first quarter. In 1995 the corresponding figures were a fall from 15.3 percent to 12.4 percent.
A CSS spokesman said the fall was due to the seasonal drop that always occurs in the second quarter, coupled with a decline in the number of overseas tourists.
"There has been quite a substantial decline in the number of tourist arrivals," he said.
This has been exacerbated by foreign tourists gradually switching from staying in hotels to using private guesthouses.

But as overseas tourists only make up about 18-20 percent of hotel occupancy rates the unusually steep fall may also be due to a drop in domestic tourism caused by a slow down in the South African economy as a whole, the spokesman added.
